text: Check that the gas supply is turned on at the meter and the isolation valve near the boiler is open.
imagePrompt: Gas meter with valve in open position

text: Press the reset button on the boiler and wait for it to attempt ignition. Listen for clicking sounds.
If the boiler still won't ignite, check the flue terminal outside for blockages (birds nests, debris).
Contact a Gas Safe registered engineer to inspect the ignition electrode, gas valve, and electrical connections.
Locate the filling loop (usually under the boiler) - it has two valves and connects the mains water to the heating system.
Slowly open both filling loop valves and watch the pressure gauge. Stop when it reaches 1.0-1.5 bar.
Close both filling loop valves tightly. Check for any leaks around the connection.
If pressure drops again quickly, there may be a leak in the system. Check radiator valves, visible pipes, and the pressure relief valve for drips. Call an engineer if leak found.
Turn off the boiler and wait 10 minutes. Turn it back on to see if the fault clears (may be temporary air lock).
Check that the pump speed is set correctly (usually marked on pump body). Medium or high setting recommended.
Feel the pump body while boiler is trying to run. If it's very hot or not vibrating, the pump may be stuck.
Contact an engineer to inspect the pump impeller, check for blockages, and possibly replace the pump if faulty.
Turn off the boiler and wait 5 minutes. Then power it back on and attempt to reset.
If fault persists, contact a Gas Safe engineer to clean or replace the flame sensor and check the combustion chamber.
IMPORTANT: Do not reset until the boiler has completely cooled down (at least 30 minutes).
Check system pressure - should be 1.0-1.5 bar. Top up if needed using the filling loop.
Feel the pump body - it should vibrate when boiler runs. If silent or very hot, pump may have failed.
Call a heating engineer to diagnose pump failure, system blockage, or thermostat fault. Do not keep resetting if overheat repeats.
Allow the boiler to cool completely (minimum 30 minutes) before attempting any further action.
Check system pressure on the gauge. If below 1 bar, use filling loop to restore pressure to 1.0-1.5 bar.
Press the reset button on the overheat thermostat (usually located on the boiler heat exchanger with a red button).
If fault repeats, call an engineer to check pump operation, system flow, and identify the cause of overheating.
Verify gas supply: Check main gas meter is on, and try other gas appliances in the home to confirm gas flow.
Check the boiler's gas isolation valve (usually near the boiler) is fully open.
Press the reset button and listen for spark clicking sounds. If no sound, there may be an electrical fault.
Contact a Gas Safe registered engineer to test gas valve operation, ignition electrode, and gas pressure.
Check pressure gauge reading. If below 1 bar (often in red zone), system needs repressurizing.
Locate and open the filling loop valves slowly. Watch pressure gauge rise to 1.0-1.5 bar, then close valves.
Reset the boiler. It should now operate normally.
If pressure drops again quickly, inspect system for leaks. Check radiator valves, pipe joints, and pressure relief valve. Call engineer if leak found.
Check the pressure gauge. System should read 1.0-1.5 bar. If low, use filling loop to restore pressure.
Reset the boiler by pressing the reset button.
If E10 returns immediately despite good pressure, the pressure sensor may be faulty. Contact a technician.
URGENT: If you smell gas when the boiler is off, evacuate the property immediately and call the gas emergency hotline.
If no gas smell, turn off the boiler and do not attempt to restart. Call a Gas Safe engineer immediately.
Engineer will test flame sensor, gas valve integrity, and control board to identify false signal source.
DANGER: This fault indicates a possible gas leak. If you smell gas, evacuate immediately and call emergency gas services (in UK: 0800 111 999).
Turn off gas supply at the meter if safe to do so. Do not operate any electrical switches.
Do not restart boiler. Wait for Gas Safe registered emergency engineer to inspect and repair.
CRITICAL SAFETY FAULT: If you smell gas, evacuate immediately and call gas emergency services.
If no gas smell, turn off boiler power and gas supply. Do not attempt to restart.
Contact Gas Safe engineer immediately for emergency inspection of gas valve and flame detection system.
